intro: Amaracarpus carolinensis, commonly known as the Carolina amaracarpus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant features palmate leaves with five to seven lobes and produces showy, pale yellow flowers with five petals. It thrives in wetland environments and is often found in swampy areas along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. The plant is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance in supporting local wildlife.
